content.html: My university has this thing called ‚ÄúAlumni Avenue‚Äù. It‚Äôs one of the air bridges between buildings, but this one is special. On this one, old masters students can engrave their names in the glass. On Monday, it was my turn, right before the graduation ceremony. It was quite an intriguing experience: I‚Äôve never engraved anything in glass, so it took quite some time to make sure it was clear and visible üòÖ There‚Äôs some pictures from the graduation, which I will post once I have access to them!

It was quite an intriguing experience: I‚Äôve never engraved anything in glass, so it took quite some time to make sure it was clear and visible üòÖ There‚Äôs some pictures from the graduation, which I will post once I have access to them!

content.html: Yesterday, I boosted (announced) a post on ActivityPub. It was automatically sent to the instance of the original post, as well as the instance of my remaining followers. Requests were successful. However, the boost only shows up in the instance of the original post. I have absolutely no clue why. W‚Ä¶

name: Yesterday, I boosted (announced) a post on ActivityPub. It was automatically sent to the instance of the original post, as well as the instance of my remaining followers. Requests were successful. However, the boost only shows up in the instance of the original post. I have absolutely no clue why. W‚Ä¶

content.html: Finally understood the problem. For Mastodon (and possibly Pleroma), a post ID is not always its URL. At least, not the URL the user usually sees. What I do now is: (1) fetch the URL from the post that I want to reply, boost or like; (2) then use that URL in the object field in the Activity I send to my followers. Seems to work successfully now.

What I do now is: (1) fetch the URL from the post that I want to reply, boost or like; (2) then use that URL in the object field in the Activity I send to my followers. Seems to work successfully now.

content.html: Yesterday, I boosted (announced) a post on ActivityPub. It was automatically sent to the instance of the original post, as well as the instance of my remaining followers. Requests were successful. However, the boost only shows up in the instance of the original post. I have absolutely no clue why. What‚Äôs the point of boosts if this is how it behaves? Maybe there‚Äôs something very obvious that I‚Äôm missing. What is it though?

Maybe there‚Äôs something very obvious that I‚Äôm missing. What is it though?

content.html: Today, we are trying to finish painting üé® the walls of the living room and kitchen. Everything else, except for one wall in the bedroom which will have a different colour, is painted. Unfortunately, I can‚Äôt help much today because I have to rest my foot due to a tendinitis, which has been a bummer. Got it in Italy but it takes a long time to recover and last week it got a bit worse. My parents are also traveling today to The Netherlands and it‚Äôs their first time going to a foreign country and second time flying. Well… they have been to Spain next to the border but that doesn‚Äôt count. So I have to ensure that my foot is the most recovered as it can to show them around a bit over next week.

content.html:
Today, Sebastiaan shared with me this nice post by Wouter, entitled ‚ÄúThe Great Mastodon Influx‚Äù. I wanted to add to that that I implemented ActivityPub a few days ago, and I‚Äôve been improving it since on my spare time. But… I am afraid. I don‚Äôt have any real followers (just myself from different instances to test). But what if I get a few followers and then get spammed with many requests? Will my tiny server in Finland handle it?

The idea of POSSEing to Mastodon doesn‚Äôt sound that bad and reduces much of the complexity associated with running a federated server. In addition, what will happen if I want to follow people? I had a very simple idea of creating a private RSS feed with incoming posts from people I would follow. The idea seems reasonably simple. But why reinvent the wheel? There‚Äôs already client apps for ActivityPub that work well. And I didn‚Äôt want to have multiple identities. Thoughts?

In addition, what will happen if I want to follow people? I had a very simple idea of creating a private RSS feed with incoming posts from people I would follow. The idea seems reasonably simple. But why reinvent the wheel? There‚Äôs already client apps for ActivityPub that work well. And I didn‚Äôt want to have multiple identities. Thoughts?

content.html: Since everyone is moving to Mastodon and such, I decided to re-add experimental support for ActivityPub in this website. The implementation is based on my old ActivityPub implementation, but it is massively improved… I think. There are still some things to do, but I feel like I will stick with it this time. However, if you want to help me test, follow me at @hacdias@hacdias.com üòú You may still see my old profile from 2020 still lingering in some instances, but if you try following me, it should work.

content.html: Today I worked from home instead of my usual co-working space, Microlab. I had a bunch of cranberries I bought the other day left. I bought them because I thought they were going to be nice and sweet but it turns out that they are extremely sour! My partner suggested me to make cranberry syrup the other day. And today I did it! All the cranberries gave two and a half bottles of nice cranberry syrup. Can‚Äôt wait to use it!

All the cranberries gave two and a half bottles of nice cranberry syrup. Can‚Äôt wait to use it!

content.html: When you rent a new apartment in a new building, you will always find interesting problems that no one discovered yet. Fortunately, the contractor has fixed most of the things we‚Äôve filled so far. Still waiting for two things to be fixed!
content.value: When you rent a new apartment in a new building, you will always find interesting problems that no one discovered yet. Fortunately, the contractor has fixed most of the things we‚Äôve filled so far. Still waiting for two things to be fixed!

content.html: My partner and I got the contract for a new apartment in the past few months. On the 8th of November, we finally got the keys for the new apartment. Being a new apartment in a new building, it comes very barebones. It is also very common in The Netherlands to rent an apartment like this. But what do I mean by ‚Äúlike this‚Äù? So the apartment has a kitchen, but no floor, no curtains and no curtain rails. It also has no lights and is not painted. We‚Äôve painted a bit last weekend and we‚Äôre getting the floor done next week. Hopefully we‚Äôll be able to move by the end of next week! So much work üòÖ

content.html: In September, I traveled to Italy with my partner. Here are some of the pictures I took at the time, finally seeing the light of the day. I took many other pictures, and it is very hard to choose what to show. Italy is such a beautiful country. We visited Napoli, Roma, Firenze, Pisa, Venezia, Bologna, Milano and Bergamo.
